A step-by-step guide to deploying your static site to GitHub Pages for free.

GitHub Pages is a free hosting service that lets you publish static websites directly from your GitHub repository. It's perfect for blogs, portfolios, documentation, and project pages.

## Why GitHub Pages?

- **Free** - No cost for public repositories
- **Simple** - Just push to GitHub
- **Fast** - Served from GitHub's CDN
- **Custom domains** - Use your own domain name
- **HTTPS** - Automatic SSL certificates

## Getting Started

### Step 1: Create a Repository

Create a new repository on GitHub. You can name it anything, but if you want it at `username.github.io`, name it exactly that.

### Step 2: Enable GitHub Pages

1. Go to your repository settings
2. Navigate to "Pages" in the left sidebar
3. Under "Source", select your branch (usually `main`)
4. Choose the folder (usually `/root` or `/docs`)
5. Click "Save"

### Step 3: Deploy Your Site

Push your static site files to the repository. GitHub Pages will automatically build and deploy your site.

## Using GitHub Actions

For more control, you can use GitHub Actions to build and deploy your site:

```yaml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
      - name: Install and Build
        run: |
          npm install
          npm run build
      - name: Deploy
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./dist
```

## Custom Domain

To use a custom domain:

1. Add a `CNAME` file to your repository with your domain
2. Configure DNS records:
   - Type: `CNAME`
   - Name: `www` (or `@` for root)
   - Value: `username.github.io`
3. Enable "Enforce HTTPS" in repository settings

## Tips

- **Build locally first** - Test your site before pushing
- **Use relative paths** - Works better with subdirectories
- **Check build logs** - GitHub Actions shows build errors
- **Be patient** - First deployment can take a few minutes

## Common Issues

**404 errors**: Make sure your `index.html` is in the right location

**Styles not loading**: Check that asset paths are correct

**Build failures**: Review GitHub Actions logs for errors

Useful Markdown syntax and best practices for writing blog posts and documentation.

Markdown is a lightweight markup language that's perfect for writing blog posts, documentation, and notes. Here are some tips to make the most of it.

## Headers

Use `#` for headers. More `#` means smaller headers:

```markdown
# H1 - Main Title
## H2 - Section
### H3 - Subsection
#### H4 - Even Smaller
```

## Emphasis

- **Bold** with `**text**` or `__text__`
- *Italic* with `*text*` or `_text_`
- ***Bold and italic*** with `***text***`
- ~~Strikethrough~~ with `~~text~~`

## Lists

### Unordered Lists

```markdown
- Item one
- Item two
  - Nested item
  - Another nested item
- Item three
```

### Ordered Lists

```markdown
1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item
```

## Code

Inline code with backticks: `const x = 10;`

Code blocks with triple backticks:

```javascript
function greet(name) {
  return `Hello, ${name}!`;
}
```

## Links and Images

- Links: `[text](https://example.com)`
- Images: `![alt text](image-url.jpg)`

## Blockquotes

> This is a blockquote. Use `>` at the start of the line.
> 
> You can have multiple paragraphs in a blockquote.

## Tables

| Column 1 | Column 2 | Column 3 |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Row 1    | Data     | More     |
| Row 2    | Data     | More     |

## Horizontal Rules

Use three dashes, asterisks, or underscores:

---

## Best Practices

1. **Use descriptive headers** - They help with navigation and SEO
2. **Keep paragraphs short** - Easier to read on screens
3. **Use lists for clarity** - Break up dense paragraphs
4. **Add code examples** - Show, don't just tell
5. **Include images** - Visual content engages readers

## Pro Tips

- Use a Markdown editor with live preview
- Learn your editor's shortcuts
- Use consistent formatting
- Preview before publishing
- Keep a style guide for consistency

{title}

Astro is a modern web framework for building fast, content-focused websites. It’s designed to ship less JavaScript to the browser, resulting in faster page loads and better performance.

What Makes Astro Special?

Astro uses a unique component islands architecture. Instead of shipping entire JavaScript frameworks to the browser, Astro only sends the interactive components that need JavaScript. The rest of your site is pure HTML and CSS.

Key Features

  • Zero JS by default - Only load JavaScript when you need it
  • Framework agnostic - Use React, Vue, Svelte, or plain HTML
  • Content-focused - Built-in support for Markdown, MDX, and content collections
  • Fast builds - Optimized for static site generation

Getting Started

To create a new Astro project, run:

npm create astro@latest

This will guide you through setting up your project with your preferred configuration.

Building Your First Page

Astro uses .astro files for components and pages. Here’s a simple example:

---
// Component script (runs at build time)
const title = "Hello, Astro!";
---

<html>
  <head>
    <title>{title}</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>{title}</h1>
  </body>
</html>

The code between --- runs at build time, while the HTML template is rendered to static HTML.

Why I Chose Astro for This Blog

I wanted a blog that:

  • Loads instantly
  • Works without JavaScript
  • Is easy to maintain
  • Deploys automatically

Astro checks all these boxes. Combined with GitHub Pages, I have a zero-cost, high-performance blog that updates automatically when I push new content.

Next Steps

If you’re interested in Astro, check out the official documentation. It’s comprehensive, well-written, and has great examples.

Happy building!

Lessons Learned Building My First App
Key takeaways from building my first application - infrastructure, costs, and performance realities.

Building your first real application is an eye-opening experience. You learn not just about coding, but about the practical realities of deploying, hosting, and maintaining software. Here are the key lessons I learned.

## Don't Overcomplicate Infrastructure

When starting out, it's tempting to set up the "perfect" infrastructure from day one. You might think you need:
- Microservices architecture
- Kubernetes clusters
- Multiple environments
- Complex CI/CD pipelines
- Service meshes
- Load balancers

**Reality check:** For most first apps, a simple monolithic application running on a single server (or serverless function) is more than enough. You can always refactor later when you actually need the complexity.

Start simple. Get something working. Ship it. Then iterate based on real needs, not hypothetical scale.

## Azure is Pricey

Cloud providers make it easy to spin up resources, but those costs add up quickly. What starts as a "free tier" experiment can quickly become a monthly bill that makes you question your life choices.

**What I learned:**
- Always set up billing alerts
- Review your costs regularly
- Consider alternatives (GitHub Pages, Vercel, Netlify for static sites)
- Don't provision resources "just in case"
- Turn off resources you're not actively using

For personal projects, the free tiers of platforms like Vercel, Netlify, or GitHub Pages are often more than sufficient. Save the enterprise cloud services for when you actually need them.

## Performance Will Suck on Lowest Settings

The cheapest cloud tier is cheap for a reason. You get:
- Limited CPU
- Minimal RAM
- Shared resources
- Slow I/O

Your app will be slow. Database queries will take forever. Response times will be measured in seconds, not milliseconds. This is fine for development and testing, but don't expect production-grade performance.

**The lesson:** If performance matters, you need to pay for it. Or architect your app to work well within constraints (caching, static generation, CDNs).

## Other Hard-Won Wisdom

- **Documentation matters** - Future you will thank present you
- **Error handling is not optional** - Users will find every edge case
- **Testing saves time** - Even basic tests catch obvious bugs
- **Deployment is hard** - But it gets easier with practice
- **Users are creative** - They'll use your app in ways you never imagined

## Conclusion

Building your first app teaches you that software development is about more than writing code. It's about making trade-offs, managing costs, and learning to ship. Start simple, learn from mistakes, and don't be afraid to rebuild when you know better.

The best infrastructure is the one that works, not the one that looks impressive on a resume.

A practical guide to building browser extensions for Chrome - from concept to publication.

Browser extensions are a great way to enhance web browsing and solve specific problems. Here's what I learned building Chrome extensions.

## Why Build an Extension?

Extensions let you:
- Modify web pages on the fly
- Add new functionality to websites
- Automate repetitive tasks
- Integrate with browser APIs
- Reach users where they already are

## Getting Started

### Basic Structure

A Chrome extension needs a `manifest.json` file:

```json
{
  "manifest_version": 3,
  "name": "My Extension",
  "version": "1.0",
  "description": "Does something useful",
  "permissions": ["activeTab"],
  "action": {
    "default_popup": "popup.html"
  },
  "content_scripts": [{
    "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
    "js": ["content.js"]
  }]
}
```

### Key Components

**Manifest V3** is the current standard. Key concepts:
- **Background Service Workers** - Run in the background
- **Content Scripts** - Inject into web pages
- **Popup** - UI that appears when clicking the extension icon
- **Options Page** - Settings page for your extension

## Common Patterns

### Content Script Injection

```javascript
// content.js
chrome.runtime.onMessage.addListener((request, sender, sendResponse) => {
  if (request.action === "modifyPage") {
    document.body.style.backgroundColor = "red";
    sendResponse({success: true});
  }
});
```

### Popup Communication

```javascript
// popup.js
document.getElementById("button").addEventListener("click", async () => {
  const [tab] = await chrome.tabs.query({active: true, currentWindow: true});
  chrome.tabs.sendMessage(tab.id, {action: "doSomething"});
});
```

## Challenges

**Permissions** - Users are (rightfully) cautious. Request only what you need.

**Cross-Origin** - Content scripts run in isolated worlds. Communication requires messaging.

**Updates** - Users need to manually update extensions. Make updates seamless.

**Testing** - Hard to test without real browser context. Use extension testing frameworks.

## Publishing

1. Create a developer account ($5 one-time fee)
2. Build your extension
3. Zip your files
4. Upload to Chrome Web Store
5. Wait for review (can take days)

## Tips

- Start with a simple idea
- Test on multiple websites
- Handle errors gracefully
- Respect user privacy
- Make it fast and lightweight
- Provide clear documentation

## Resources

- [Chrome Extension Documentation](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/)
- [Manifest V3 Migration Guide](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/mv3/intro/)
- [Extension Examples](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/chrome-extensions-samples)

How I built EngageX faster than I thought possible - lessons in rapid development and focused execution.

Speedrunning isn't just for video games. Sometimes you need to build something fast - really fast. Here's how I built EngageX in record time.

## What is EngageX?

EngageX was a project that needed to be done quickly. The goal: build a functional, useful application in the shortest time possible without sacrificing too much quality.

## The Strategy

### 1. Ruthless Prioritization

Not every feature is essential. I made a list:
- **Must have** - Core functionality only
- **Nice to have** - Can add later
- **Never** - Out of scope

I only built the "must have" features. Everything else could wait.

### 2. Use What You Know

No time for learning new frameworks. I stuck with:
- Technologies I already knew
- Patterns I'd used before
- Libraries I was familiar with

Learning happens on personal time, not during speedruns.

### 3. Copy, Don't Create

Why write code when you can:
- Use existing libraries
- Copy patterns from other projects
- Leverage templates and starters
- Reference documentation examples

Originality is overrated when speed matters.

### 4. Skip the Nice-to-Haves

I skipped:
- Comprehensive error handling (basic only)
- Extensive testing (manual testing only)
- Beautiful UI (functional is fine)
- Documentation (code comments only)
- Optimization (make it work first)

These can all be added later if the project succeeds.

### 5. Time Boxing

I set strict time limits:
- Day 1: Core architecture
- Day 2: Main features
- Day 3: Polish and deploy

No feature creep. No "just one more thing."

## What I Learned

**Speed forces focus** - When time is limited, you make better decisions about what actually matters.

**Good enough is good enough** - Perfect is the enemy of done. Ship something that works.

**Iteration beats planning** - Building teaches you more than planning ever will.

**Constraints are liberating** - Having less time means less second-guessing.

## The Result

EngageX shipped on time. It wasn't perfect, but it worked. And that's what mattered.

## Would I Do It Again?

Absolutely. Speedrunning teaches you:
- What you can actually build in a day
- What features you can live without
- How to make hard decisions quickly
- That shipping beats perfection

Sometimes the best way to learn is to go fast and see what breaks. Then fix it. Or don't. Either way, you've learned something.

How a single button click led to understanding Domain-Driven Design and refactoring a monolith.

Sometimes the smallest change can reveal the biggest problems. This is the story of how clicking a button made me realize I needed Domain-Driven Design.

## The Button

It was just a button. A simple "Submit" button in a form. Click it, data gets saved, user sees confirmation. Standard stuff.

But when I clicked it, nothing happened. No error. No loading state. Just... nothing.

## The Investigation

I started digging. The button called a function. That function called a service. That service called a repository. That repository called a database. Somewhere in that chain, something was broken.

But where?

## The Problem

The codebase was a classic monolith:
- Business logic mixed with UI code
- Database queries scattered everywhere

- How the data layer worked

## The Realization

This wasn't just about a broken button. This was about architecture. The codebase had no clear domain boundaries. Everything was connected to everything else.

I needed Domain-Driven Design.

## What is DDD?

Domain-Driven Design is about:
- **Bounded Contexts** - Clear boundaries between different parts of your system
- **Ubiquitous Language** - Using the same terms your business uses
- **Aggregates** - Clusters of related entities
- **Domain Models** - Code that reflects business concepts

Instead of thinking about "services" and "repositories," think about "Orders," "Customers," "Products" - the actual things your business deals with.

I started small. I identified one domain - let's say "Orders." I:
1. Defined what an Order actually is in business terms
2. Created a clear boundary around Order-related code
3. Moved all Order logic into one place
4. Made the Order domain independent of other domains

Suddenly, fixing the button was easy. The Order domain had clear responsibilities. I knew exactly where to look.

**Small boundaries first** - You don't need to refactor everything at once.

**Language matters** - Using business terms in code makes it easier to understand.

**Isolation helps** - Clear boundaries make testing and debugging easier.

An honest take on Storybook - why it's not for everyone and when to skip it.

Let me be clear: I hate Storybook. Not because it's bad software - it's actually quite good. I hate it because of what it represents and when it's used.

## What is Storybook?

Storybook is a tool for developing and testing UI components in isolation. You write "stories" that show your components in different states, and you can interact with them outside of your main application.

It's popular. It's well-maintained. It's used by many successful teams.

I still hate it.

## Why I Hate It

### 1. The Setup Overhead

Getting Storybook working isn't trivial:
- Install dependencies
- Configure webpack/vite
- Write stories for every component
- Maintain those stories as components change
- Keep stories in sync with actual usage

For a small project, this is massive overhead. The time spent setting up Storybook could be spent building features.

### 2. False Confidence

Stories show components in isolation. But components don't live in isolation. They live in:
- Real pages with real data
- Different screen sizes
- Various user states
- Complex interaction flows

A component that looks great in Storybook might break in context. Storybook gives you confidence that might be misplaced.

### 3. Maintenance Burden

Every component change means updating stories. Every new prop means new story variants. Every refactor means rewriting stories.

It's like writing tests, but for visual components. And like tests, they need to be maintained. Unlike tests, they don't catch bugs - they just show what components look like.

### 4. The Documentation Lie

"Storybook is living documentation!" No, it's not. Documentation explains *why* and *how*. Storybook shows *what*. 

Real documentation is:
- When to use a component
- What props mean
- Common patterns
- Edge cases
- Accessibility considerations

Storybook shows you the component. It doesn't explain it.

## When Storybook Makes Sense

I'll admit it: Storybook has its place.

**Large design systems** - When you have dozens of components used across multiple projects, Storybook helps.

**Designer-developer collaboration** - When designers need to see components without running the app.

**Complex component libraries** - When you're building a library for others to use.

**Large teams** - When multiple developers need to understand available components.

## When to Skip It

**Small projects** - The overhead isn't worth it.

**Tight deadlines** - You don't have time for setup and maintenance.

**Simple components** - If your components are straightforward, Storybook adds little value.

**Solo developers** - You know your own components. You don't need a catalog.

## Alternatives

Instead of Storybook, consider:
- **Component tests** - Actually test behavior, not just appearance
- **Real pages** - Develop components in their actual context
- **Screenshots** - Capture real usage, not isolated states
- **Documentation** - Write actual docs explaining components

## The Real Problem

My issue isn't really with Storybook. It's with the assumption that every project needs it. That component development requires isolation. That visual testing is essential.

Sometimes the best way to develop a component is to use it. In your app. With real data. In context.

Storybook is a tool. Use it when it helps. Skip it when it doesn't. And don't let anyone tell you that good development requires Storybook.

I hate Storybook. But I hate cargo-cult development practices more.

A digital nomad's honest review of Chiang Mai, Thailand - the good, the bad, and the WiFi speeds.

Chiang Mai has been a digital nomad hotspot for years. After spending time there, here's my honest take on what it's really like.

## The Good

### Cost of Living

Chiang Mai is cheap. Really cheap.
- Accommodation: $200-500/month for a decent place
- Food: $2-5 for excellent local meals
- Coffee: $1-2 for good coffee
- Coworking: $50-100/month

You can live comfortably on $1000/month. That's hard to beat.

### Food Scene

The food is incredible. From street food to upscale restaurants, Chiang Mai has it all:
- Khao Soi (curry noodle soup) - a must-try
- Street food markets every night
- International options if you need a break
- Fresh fruit everywhere

### Community

The digital nomad community is large and welcoming:
- Regular meetups and events
- Coworking spaces full of remote workers
- Easy to make friends
- Supportive community

### Nature and Culture

Chiang Mai isn't just about working:
- Temples everywhere
- Mountains nearby for hiking
- Elephant sanctuaries (ethical ones)
- Night markets
- Old city charm

## The Bad

### Air Quality

The burning season (February-April) is brutal. The air quality index can hit 200+ (unhealthy). If you have respiratory issues, avoid these months.

### Internet Reliability

While many places have good WiFi, it's not guaranteed:
- Power outages happen
- Internet can be slow during peak hours
- Some areas have spotty coverage
- Always have a backup (mobile hotspot)

### Tourist Traps

The old city is beautiful but touristy:
- Overpriced restaurants
- Touts everywhere
- Crowded during high season
- Less authentic experiences

### Visa Situation

Tourist visas are limited:
- 30 days visa-free (for many countries)
- Can extend once for 30 more days
- After that, you need to leave or get a proper visa
- Visa runs are common but getting stricter

## The Reality

### Working There

Coworking spaces are good but not great:
- Punspace and CAMP are popular
- WiFi is usually reliable
- Air conditioning is essential
- Can get crowded during peak hours

Cafes are hit or miss:
- Some have great WiFi and power outlets
- Others are too loud or don't allow long stays
- Coffee quality varies wildly

### Living There

Chiang Mai is a city, not a resort:
- Traffic can be bad
- Pollution (outside burning season) is still an issue
- Infrastructure is developing but not perfect
- Language barrier exists (though many speak English)

### Is It Worth It?

**Yes, if:**
- You want to save money
- You're okay with some inconveniences
- You value community and networking
- You want to experience Thai culture

**No, if:**
- You need perfect internet reliability
- Air quality is a concern
- You want a resort-like experience
- You need Western amenities

## My Verdict

Chiang Mai is a great place to work remotely, but it's not perfect. The low cost and strong community make it attractive, but you trade some comforts for those benefits.

I'd go back, but I'd avoid burning season and have backup internet plans. It's a solid choice for digital nomads, but manage your expectations.

A digital nomad's review of Bansko, Bulgaria - Europe's affordable nomad destination.

Bansko, Bulgaria has emerged as a digital nomad destination in Europe. Here's what it's really like to work and live there.

## The Good

### Affordability

Bansko is cheap for Europe:
- Accommodation: $300-600/month
- Food: $5-10 for good meals
- Coworking: $50-80/month
- Ski pass (winter): Included with many accommodations

You can live well on $1200-1500/month, which is excellent for Europe.

### Coworking Scene

The coworking spaces are actually good:
- Coworking Bansko is well-equipped
- Good WiFi (usually)
- Community events
- Networking opportunities
- Some spaces include accommodation

### Nature

Bansko is in the mountains:
- Hiking trails everywhere
- Skiing in winter
- Beautiful scenery
- Fresh air
- Outdoor activities

### Community

The nomad community is growing:
- Regular events and meetups
- Friendly people
- Easy to connect
- Supportive atmosphere

## The Bad

### Internet Issues

This is the biggest problem:
- WiFi can be unreliable
- Power outages happen
- Some areas have slow speeds
- Mobile data is a must-have backup
- Not all accommodations have good internet

**This is a real issue for remote work.** Always verify internet before booking long-term.

### Small Town Limitations

Bansko is small:
- Limited restaurant options
- Not much nightlife
- Fewer amenities than cities
- Can feel isolated
- Limited shopping

### Language Barrier

Bulgarian is the main language:
- English is spoken in tourist/nomad areas
- Outside those areas, communication is harder
- Learning some Bulgarian helps
- Not as English-friendly as other nomad spots

### Seasonal Variation

Bansko is very different by season:
- **Winter**: Busy, expensive, cold, great for skiing
- **Summer**: Quiet, affordable, warm, great for hiking
- **Shoulder seasons**: Best balance

## The Reality

### Working There

**Coworking spaces:**
- Generally good but can get crowded
- WiFi reliability varies
- Some have great communities
- Worth the cost for reliability

**Working from accommodation:**
- Risky - internet quality varies
- Always have a backup plan
- Mobile hotspot is essential
- Test before committing long-term

### Living There

**Accommodation:**
- Lots of options (apartments, hostels, hotels)
- Prices vary by season
- Many include utilities
- Some include ski passes (winter)

**Food:**
- Bulgarian food is hearty and cheap
- International options limited
- Good bakeries
- Supermarkets well-stocked

**Getting around:**
- Town is walkable
- Car helpful for exploring
- Public transport exists but limited
- Taxis are cheap

### Is It Worth It?

**Yes, if:**
- You want affordable Europe
- You love mountains/nature
- You can handle internet uncertainty
- You value community
- You're okay with small-town life

**No, if:**
- You need guaranteed fast internet
- You want city amenities
- You need consistent connectivity
- You prefer warm weather year-round
- You want lots of entertainment options

## My Verdict

Bansko is a solid choice for digital nomads who:
- Want to save money in Europe
- Can handle some internet uncertainty
- Enjoy outdoor activities
- Value community over amenities

The internet situation is the main drawback. If you can work around that (backup connections, flexible schedule), Bansko offers great value.

It's not perfect, but for the price in Europe, it's hard to beat. Just come prepared with backup internet and realistic expectations.
